IntroductionSection.Title: [ES]Have a direct impact on the future of cancer research.
IntroductionSection.Text: [ES]Count Me In is a nonprofit research initiative that engages patients and enables them to accelerate cancer research by sharing their samples, their clinical information, and their voices.

LearnMoreSection.Title: [ES]Every patient's experience with cancer should be counted.
LearnMoreSection.Text: [ES]Patients’ medical records, tumor samples, and personal experiences hold clues—about which cancers will respond or become resistant to which therapies—that often can’t be found in research labs or clinical trials. Count Me In enables cancer patients anywhere to share their information with researchers everywhere, to help reveal patterns in the data.

JoinSection.Title: [ES]Who can join?
JoinSection.Text1: [ES]Anyone who has ever been diagnosed with cancer may participate if they live in the USA or Canada.
JoinSection.Text2: [ES]We welcome people of all ages, genders, races, ethnicities, and abilities.
JoinSection.ImageAlt: [ES]Map dotted with participants across the U.S. and Canada.

Steps.Title: PASO 1
Steps.Description: [ES]Provide consent and tell us where you’ve been treated

Steps.Title: PASO 4
Steps.ImageAlt: [ES]Speech bubbles sharing hearts and data visualizations

StayInformedSection.Title: Manténgase informado
StayInformedSection.Text: [ES]Sign up for our mailing list or follow us on social media

CountMeInSection.Title: [ES]Join the movement and say Count Me In
CountMeInSection.Text: [ES]With your help, patients can be the driving force behind transformative cancer research.

Steps.Title: [ES]Provide consent for the study
Steps.Text: [ES]This section consists of several pages, but feel free to take your time. Your progress will be automatically saved so you can come back to it later. If you are signing up for / with your child, depending on their age, we may also ask them to “assent” or agree that they would also like to participate in the study.

Steps.Title: [ES]Tell us where you’ve been treated
Steps.Text: [ES]Tell us where you’ve been treated for your cancer. We ask where patients have been treated, so that we can request medical records, and if applicable, archived tumor tissue.

Steps.Title: [ES]Respond to surveys about you and your experience with cancer
Steps.Text: [ES]In these surveys, we ask questions about your experience with cancer, like what type of cancer you were diagnosed with, when you were diagnosed, and the types of treatments you’ve had.

Steps.Title: [ES]Provide a saliva and/or blood sample
Steps.Text: [ES]We will send you a kit to collect a sample of your saliva and/or blood. We will study these samples to help improve our understanding of cancer.

Steps.Title: [ES]Stay involved
Steps.Text: [ES]Over time, we will provide you with regular updates about the status of the research and share any discoveries that you have enabled us to make. We also may ask you additional questions about your experience to help with future studies — we want to hear what’s important to you.
Steps.ImageAlt: [ES]Speech bubbles sharing hearts and data visualizations

Sections.Title: [ES]Goals
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In is a patient-partnered cancer research study open to anyone in the United States or Canada who has ever been diagnosed with cancer. The goal of Count Me In is to transform cancer care by enabling all cancer patients to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. This partnership generates cancer datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data without including any personal information. In order to accelerate the pace at which discoveries are made, Count Me In data is regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.

[ES]Everyone who signs up for Count Me In will be able to provide saliva samples as well as patient-reported data through a series of surveys on topics such as their clinical history, their experiences with cancer, and their family history of cancer. There is tremendous scientific value in studying this large, cross-cutting group of patients who represent many different cancer types, treating institutions, and ages or other demographics. The more that participants in research truly represent the full diversity of cancer patients and their experiences, the greater the impact that scientific discoveries can have for everyone.

[ES]Additional biological samples, such as tumor samples, blood samples, and still samples, will be obtained from specific patient cohorts and used to generate genomic and molecular data for analysis. This resulting data will be linked to the genomic data from saliva samples, the clinical information from medical records, and patient-reported information from surveys, which will be shared with the biomedical research community. By integrating all of these different and important aspects of cancer, resulting Count Me In datasets will accelerate research discoveries across many different fields.

[ES]This approach of Count Me In enables building and deeply studying cohorts of patients not only within one cancer type, but also that cut across cancer types -- such as all patients who receive a particular therapy, such as immunotherapy; or patients within a particular age group, such as adolescents and young adults. Count Me In has built and will continue to build research initiatives around different patient populations and cohorts. As more people join, there will be more opportunities to launch deeper studies within more patient cohorts.

Sections.Title: [ES]Impact
Paragraphs: [ES]To date, more than 8,500 patients across the United States and Canada have registered to participate in Count Me In research projects, spanning several diverse cancer types. The Count Me In team would like to thank each patient who has participated.
[ES]With this deep partnership, substantial data has been generated resulting in more than ten releases of data in scientific repositories across existing Count Me In projects.

[ES]Scientists from around the world have used Count Me In data in order to make discoveries in many different areas and to establish new clinical trials, such as in angiosarcoma. We have heard directly from more than 60 scientists working in academic and industry settings in over ten countries who are using Count Me In data to catalyze their research.
[ES]The results of studies utilizing Count Me In data are being widely disseminated in scientific publications, with over 50 citations of Count Me In datasets to date.

Examples.Title: [ES]Here are a few examples of publications using data from Count Me In projects:

Links.Title: [ES]Proline rich 11 (PRR11) overexpression amplifies PI3K signaling and promotes antiestrogen resistance in breast cancer.
[ES]Prevalence and mutational determinants of high tumor mutation burden in breast cancer.
[ES]The Angiosarcoma Project: enabling genomic and clinical discoveries in a rare cancer through patient-partnered research.

Sections.FinalText: [ES]The collective impact of Count Me In and patient participants will continue to expand as the work of Count Me In is ongoing. There are more patient partners registering to participate every day, additional projects that will be launched, expanded datasets that will be generated and shared, and further discoveries that will be made to improve the lives of cancer patients.

Sections.Title: Misión
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In is a nonprofit organization catalyzing research initiatives that take a unique approach to cancer research. Count Me In is deeply committed to making every patient's experience count in the effort to more deeply understand cancer. We do this by working directly with patients as partners to accelerate discoveries. We seek to empower individuals living with cancer, including those from marginalized communities who have historically been excluded from research, no matter where they live, to contribute to breakthroughs and increase the pace of biomedical research.

[ES]Participating patients help shape and propel research, including by contributing information about their cancer and experience through patient surveys, and also by directly sharing and providing access to medical records and biological samples for study and analysis. From participant contributions, the Count Me In team works with software engineers and computational scientists, to collect, analyze, and share de-identified data. Data generated by Count Me In is shared regularly via scientific platforms so that it can be harnessed by researchers everywhere to make impactful discoveries.

Sections.Title: [ES]History and Milestones
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In (CMI) began with discussions between Emerson Collective and the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard in 2013. Since the launch of the first project in metastatic breast cancer in late 2015, thousands of individuals living with cancer from around the United States and Canada have said “Count Me In” to partnering with researchers and sharing their experiences. The Metastatic Breast Cancer (MBC) project was the first iteration of this new vision, followed by the Angiosarcoma (ASC) Project in 2017, and the Metastatic Prostate Cancer (MPC) Project in 2018. Since then, CMI has also launched the Esophageal and Stomach Cancer Project, the Osteosarcoma (OS) Project, and the Brain Tumor (BT) Project. In Fall 2021, enrollment in Count Me In became available to any patient in the United States or Canada who has ever been diagnosed with cancer.

[ES]Count Me In is stewarded by the Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; and the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital.

Questions.Question: [ES]What is Count Me In?
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In is a nonprofit research initiative that enables patients to accelerate cancer research by sharing their samples, their clinical information, and their voices. With patient consent, all data collected by and generated through Count Me In are shared regularly with the research community (after being stripped of identifying information) through freely available scientific databases, so researchers anywhere can help rapidly accelerate the pace of discovery, expand our understanding of cancer, and develop new treatment strategies – breaking down silos that exist in cancer research.

Questions.Question: [ES]Why is this needed?
Paragraphs:
[ES]Patients have the power to advance cancer research in a way that no one else can. Patients’ medical records, tumor samples, and personal experiences hold clues—about which cancers will respond or become resistant to which therapies — that often can’t be found in research labs or clinical trials.
The majority of patients have never had the opportunity to participate in research—because most cancer patients are cared for in community settings where this type of research is not done; most patients have never been asked if they’d like to contribute their tissue samples and medical information for research.
Answering many important questions about cancer will require engaging and empowering many more patients as partners, and offering the opportunity to participate in groundbreaking research to all people living with cancer, whether they live near a research hospital or not. Count Me In aims to help make that possible.

Questions.Question: [ES]How can I participate?
Paragraphs: [ES]If you or your child have ever been diagnosed with cancer, and reside in the United States, United States territories- including Puerto Rico, or Canada, you can sign up by clicking “Count Me In”. Click here to learn more about participation.

[ES]If you’re a cancer researcher, you can access the data generated through Count Me In projects through existing publicly available databases, such as the cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute’s Genomic Data Commons. You can also join our mailing list for updates about new data releases and publications.

Questions.Question: [ES]What does Count Me In do with the data?
Paragraphs: [ES]After removing all personal information that would readily identify individuals, data is shared freely in an effort to accelerate discoveries, enabling researchers to identify patterns in data. Batches of data are released publicly on a regular basis, and are available to all researchers—so that everyone may use the data to make discoveries and advance progress against cancer, including new medicines and diagnostics.

[ES]Quick links to released data:
https://www.mbcproject.org/data-release
https://ascproject.org/data-release

Questions.Question: [ES]How have patients been involved in Count Me In?
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In has worked closely with patients, parents, loved ones and patient advocates within several cancer communities from the beginning of the first project, the Metastatic Breast Cancer Project, launched in 2015. Patients have been included in all aspects of the design including concept, goals, messaging, forms, and the website.

Questions.Question: [ES]How is Count Me In addressing inclusivity in participation?
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In understands that many barriers exist - structural and historical - that prevent underrepresented and marginalized communities from directly participating in research. Count Me In is committed to the core principle that every cancer patient, regardless of where they live, what language they speak, what their heritage may be - that their experience matters and the inclusion of their experience is imperative in furthering our understanding of cancer.

[ES]Traditional cancer research does not lend itself to being as inclusive as it should be. Cancer disparities exist as evidence of how much more work in this space needs to be done - and it’s one in which we recognize that we’ll never truly arrive - but continue to strive for, alongside patients. We believe patients should be direct partners in cancer research and know that we can only advance our understanding of cancer and accelerate discoveries, if we do so together.

Questions.Question: [ES]How can I receive updates on Count Me In?
[ES]Will I be paid to take part in this research study?
Paragraphs: [ES]You will not be paid to take part in this study.

Questions.Question: [ES]Are there costs to take part in this research study?
Paragraphs: [ES]There are no costs to take part in this study.

Questions.Question: [ES]Is this a clinical trial?
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In is not a clinical trial. Joining will not have any impact on a participant’s course of care, and Count Me In is not permitted to give any clinical advice as part of participation in this project.

Questions.Question: [ES]Can I stop taking part in Count Me In?
Paragraphs: [ES]You can stop participating in Count Me In at any time. However, information that has already been used for research will not be able to be withdrawn. To withdraw your permission, reach out to the study team at info@joincountmein.org.

[ES]If you withdraw, any remaining tissue samples will be returned to where they were obtained, and any remaining saliva and/or blood samples will be destroyed. No additional tests will be performed on the samples. Additionally, no additional medical records will be collected, and any copies of medical records will be destroyed. However, the results from the tests done and any information learned from your medical records before you stopped participating will be kept.

Questions.Question: [ES]If I choose to share tissue sample(s), will my samples be used up?
Paragraphs: [ES]Count Me In will take every measure to ensure that samples are not used up as a result of these studies. Pathologists who have access to stored tumor samples will be asked to share only a small portion. If there doesn’t appear to be enough to allow for future clinical testing, Count Me In will not request for samples. Any excess tissue will be sent back.

Questions.Question: [ES]What does Count Me In do with copies of medical records?
Paragraphs: [ES]Medical records provide valuable information about experiences with cancer. From medical records, researchers can learn important details like what treatments you received and how long you received them for, details about the pathology of your tumor(s), information about your cancer at diagnosis, and more.
[ES]For researchers studying cancer, it is valuable to be able to look at medical record information with the information from your samples in order to make discoveries.

Questions.Question: [ES]Why is Count Me In studying specific cohorts?
Paragraphs: [ES]A cohort is a group of people sharing a similar set of characteristics. This could include various demographic information, cancer types, mutation types, responses to treatment, and more. By studying specific cohorts in-depth, researchers can find patterns and detect trends that may help us better understand various aspects of cancer.

Questions.Question: [ES]If I have signed up on behalf of my child, what happens when they become an adult?
Paragraphs: [ES]When your child reaches the age where they can consent for themselves, they need to do so to continue to participate. For the US and Canada, this varies by state and territory, and is between ages of 18 and 21. Count Me In will contact you prior to this age to get your child’s contact information.
[ES]If your child chooses to remain in the study  the project team will continue to request medical records and tissue samples from any point in your child’s cancer treatment.

Footer.Copyright: [ES]Copyright © 2021 Count Me In. All rights reserved.

SessionWillExpire.Title: Su sesión terminará pronto
SessionWillExpire.Text: Para proteger su privacidad, este sistema cerrará su sesión por falta de inactividad. Haga clic en “Continuar” para mantenerse conectado. Haga clic en “Cerrar Sesión” si ha terminado por ahora
SessionWillExpire.RenewalFailed: No se pudo renovar la sesión. Por favor cierre la sesión y vuelva a intentar.

StudyRedirect.Title: [ES]Your participation
StudyRedirect.Text1: [ES]Count Me In has an open project specific to your cancer type.
StudyRedirect.Text2: [ES]Use the button below to join the {{study}} and learn more about this existing work.

Warning.Title: Descarge Chrome o Safari para continuar
Warning.Text1: Este proyecto esta diseñado para su uso con los navegadores de internet mas populares y seguros -- Chrome y Safari.
Warning.Text2: Parece que está utilizando Internet Explorer. Deberá utilizar otro navegador para unirse al proyecto. Le sugerimos que utilice Chrome o Safari para asegurarse de que su experiencia con el sitio web sea fluida y segura.

Text3.Pt1: Haga clic en los siguientes enlaces para descargar
Text3.Pt3: Chrome y Safari siempre son gratis.

SDK.ValidateError: Por favor complete todos los campos requeridos.
SDK.CommunicationError: Hubo un problema al guardar sus datos. Revise el formulario y sus respuestas antes de enviar todo.

Suggestion.Title: Hemos verificado la dirección que ingresó y le sugerimos cambios para ayudar a que la entrega se haga correctamente.
Suggestion.Subtitle: Haga clic en “Sugerencias” para actualizar el formulario. Podrá hacer clic en la opción “Datos originales” para que los datos queden tal como estaban.

Error.CannotVerify: No pudimos verificar la dirección. Revise si es correcta.
Error.UnknownVerifyError: Se produjo un error desconocido al verificar la dirección.
Error.FieldIsInvalid: El campo {{field}} tiene un valor no válido.
Error.InvalidHouseNumber: No se encontró el número de la calle.
Error.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR: Lamentablemente, algo salió mal. Si el problema continúa, envíe un mensaje a support@easypost.com.
Error.NOT_ACCEPTABLE: El recurso detectado por la solicitud solo puede generar entidades de respuesta cuyo contenido tiene características inaceptables según los encabezados aceptables enviados en la solicitud.
Error.NOT_FOUND: No se encontró el recurso solicitado.
Error.FORBIDDEN: No se puede acceder al recurso solicitado.
Error.PAYMENT_REQUIRED: Fondos insuficientes. Verifique las opciones de facturación en http://www.easypost.com/account/billing.
Error.UNAUTHORIZED: No se puede acceder al recurso solicitado. Hubo un error de autorización.
Error.BAD_REQUEST: Solicitud con estructura incorrecta. Verifique el contenido y vuelva a intentarlo.
Error.PAYMENT_GATEWAY.ERROR: El procesador de pagos no pudo gestionar la solicitud. Vuelva a intentarlo o envíe un mensaje a support@easypost.com si el problema continúa.
Error.MODE.UNAUTHORIZED: Este recurso requiere una clave API de producción para permitir el acceso.
Error.MODE.CONFLICT: El modo de la clave API está en conflicto con el modo de los parámetros.
Error.DATE.PARSE.FAILURE: Al menos una fecha tiene un formato incorrecto y no se pudo analizar.
Error.PARAMETER.FORBIDDEN: La solicitud no se pudo llevar a cabo porque los parámetros tienen propiedades prohibidas.
Error.ADDRESS.PARAMETERS.INVALID_CHARACTER: Los parámetros utilizados tenían un carácter no válido.
Error.ADDRESS.PARAMETERS.INVALID: Faltan los parámetros utilizados para crear la dirección o no son válidos.
Error.ADDRESS.COUNTRY.INVALID: País no válido. Indique un código de país ISO de dos caracteres.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFICATION.FAILURE: No se pudo verificar la dirección.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.UNAVAILABLE: No es posible verificar la dirección. Vuelva a intentarlo.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFICATION.INVALID: Una de las verificaciones seleccionadas no es válida.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.FAILURE: No se pudo verificar la dirección.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.CARRIER_INVALID: No se puede verificar la dirección con el proveedor indicado.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.UPSTREAM_UNAVAILABLE: No se puede verificar la dirección porque un servicio en la secuencia no responde. Vuelva a intentarlo.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.ONLY_US: USPS solo permite validar direcciones de EE. UU.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.INTL_NOT_ENABLED: En esta cuenta no se permite la verificación internacional. Envíe un mensaje a support@easypost.com.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.MISSING_STREET: No se indicaron suficientes datos para la dirección. Se debe indicar una calle.
Error.ADDRESS.VERIFY.MISSING_CITY_STATE_ZIP: No se indicaron suficientes datos para la dirección. Se deben indicar una ciudad y un estado o un código postal.
Error.E.COUNTRY.UNSUPPORTED: Este país no se admite en este modo. Intente con el modo de producción.
Error.E.ENGINE.UNAVAILABLE: No hay ningún motor de verificación para prestar servicio a este país. Vuelva a intentarlo más tarde.
Error.E.QUERY.UNANSWERABLE: No podemos brindar suficientes datos en este país para llevar a cabo esa solicitud. Vuelva a intentarlo más tarde.
Error.E.SECONDARY_INFORMATION.INVALID: Información secundaria no válida (N.º de apartamento/oficina). Tenga en cuenta que eso puede causar errores en solicitudes correctas.
Error.E.SECONDARY_INFORMATION.MISSING: Falta información secundaria (N.º de apartamento/oficina). Tenga en cuenta que eso puede causar errores en solicitudes correctas.
Error.E.HOUSE_NUMBER.INVALID: No encontramos el número de calle indicado.
Error.E.BOX_NUMBER.MISSING: Falta el número de casilla postal.
Error.E.BOX_NUMBER.INVALID: El número de casilla postal no es válido.
Error.E.ZIP.NOT_FOUND: No se encontró el código postal.
Error.E.ZIP.PLUS4.NOT_FOUND: No se encontró el código postal + 4.
Error.E.ADDRESS.MULTIPLE: Encontramos varias direcciones con el mismo código postal.
Error.E.TIMED_OUT: Se superó el tiempo máximo de espera.
Error.E.TIME_ZONE.UNAVAILABLE: El servicio de zona horaria no está disponible en este momento.
Error.E.PO_BOX.INTERNATIONAL: No se puede verificar la casilla postal internacional. Tenga en cuenta que eso puede causar errores en solicitudes correctas.
